description:
Lepisosteus oculatus, commonly known as the spotted gar, is a species of freshwater fish belonging to the family Lepisosteidae, also known as the gars. The spotted gar is native to the central and southeastern United States, primarily found in the Mississippi River basin and coastal areas of the Gulf of Mexico.

The spotted gar is a long, slender fish with a distinctive elongated, bony snout and a body covered in thick, diamond-shaped scales. Its coloration is typically olive-green or brown on the dorsal side, with a white or yellowish ventral surface. The most distinctive feature of the species is the presence of numerous small, dark spots along the body and fins, which gives it the common name "spotted gar."

Spotted gars are predatory fish, feeding primarily on smaller fish, crustaceans, and aquatic insects. They have a unique respiratory system, possessing a modified swim bladder that allows them to take in air directly, enabling them to survive in low-oxygen environments. Spotted gars are known to be capable of jumping out of the water and can even move short distances on land.

Lepisosteus oculatus is an important part of the freshwater ecosystem, serving as both a predator and prey species. The species is considered to be of least concern on the IUCN Red List, although some populations may face threats from habitat degradation and pollution.
